She is requesting a loan for 2000 nuevos soles [Peruvian currency] through Edpyme Alternativa that she will use to buy merchandise for her store and a flower stand.  Additionally, part of the loan will be used to make improvements to the interior of her house and for her most pressing personal expenses.

loans.use: purchase merchandise for her store and a flower stand as well as for home improvements and personal expenses.

loans.name: Reynaldo  Santiago

texts.es:
En el municipio de Managua, el señor Reynaldo es una persona trabajadora y de buenos valores morales dedicandose a laborar como colector, desde hace seis años. Es soltero y tiene una persona a su cargo.

Actualmente ha tenido una dificultad y es que su mamá ha estado mal de salud por lo que él ha acudido a Ceprodel con el fin de solicitar un crédito  para suplir los gasto médicos tales como el pago de examenes medicos, pago de consultas y la compra de los medicamentos para la pronta recuperación de su mamá.
texts.en:
Reynaldo, a hardworking person with good moral values, lives in the city of Managua. He has worked as a collector for 6 years. He is single and has one dependent. 

At present, he has been struggling because his mother is in poor health and he has come to Ceprodel with the purpose of requesting a loan to cover medical expenses for his mother, such as doctors visits and medicine for her quick recovery.

loans.use: to buy medicine and pay for his mother's doctors visits.

loans.name: Normumin

texts.ru: Нормумин проживает в районе Шахритус. Ему 54 года. Он женат. У него четверо детей. Его жена работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Сам Нормумин занимается животноводством и одновременно растениеводством. Он зарабатывает путем разведения крупнорогатого скота. Кроме того при доме у него имеется участок земли, где он выращивает овощи. В этой области он уже 16 лет. Кредит берет для закупа крупнорогатого скота.
texts.en: Normumin lives in the Shahrituz region. He is 54 years old. He is married and has four children. His wife works in the communal farm. Normumin does animal husbandry and also agriculture. He makes a living by breeding large horned cattle. Besides that he has a plot of land by his home where he grows vegetables. He has been in this business for sixteen years. He is taking out the loan to buy large horned cattle.

loans.use: to buy large horned cattle

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
Marina nació en la ciudad del Cusco (Perú) y tiene 40 años de edad, ella tiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene cuatro hijos. Actualmente, ella vive en la misma  ciudad donde nació y donde realiza sus actividades, ella desde hace 11 años que tiene una molinera, ella compra trigo, habas, cebada y otros granos secos, estos productos los procesa y los convierte en productos alimenticios nutricionales.   
 
Marina requiere el préstamo para compra granos secos como maíz, cebada, trigo, kiwicha y otros más. 

El Banco Comunal “Siempre Adelante” se reúne cada treinta en la ciudad del Cusco (Perú). Cusco es conocido por ser una zona muy turística, comercial, por su fiesta tradicional del Inti Raymi y porque se encuentra una de las siete maravillas del mundo “Machupicchu”.
texts.en:
Marina was born in the city of Cusco (Perú) and she’s 40 years old.  She’s in a common law relationship and has four children.  She currently lives in the city of her birth where she also carries out her activities.  She’s had a mill for the last 11 years.  She buys wheat, broad beans, barley and other dry grains that she processes and turns into nutritional foodstuffs.  Marina needs the loan to buy dry grains like corn, barley, wheat, kiwicha [amaranth] and others.

The “Siempre Adelante” (Always Forward) communal bank meets every thirty days in the city of Cusco (Perú). Cusco is known for tourism, commerce, for its traditional “Inti Raymi” festival and because one of the Seven Wonders of the World, Machupicchu, is located here.

loans.use: to buy dry grains.

loans.name: Hao

texts.en:
Hao was born in 1969. She lives in Phan Xa village, Uy No commune. She has two children who are going to school. Her husband is a worker. Her main job is farming. She grows rice and raises pigs. 

Since 2005 she has participated in SEDA and always repaid loans punctually. The last time, she borrowed 7,194,000 Vietnamese dong (VND). For this loan, she would like to borrow 8,398,000 VND to buy pigs.

loans.use: to buy pigs

loans.name: Juvelinda

texts.en:
Raising hogs to fatten and sell in the future is Juvelinda's business. She started it five years ago. She is married to a local framer named Edwin and was blessed with four children. She is engaged in a business to meet their daily needs and the allowances of her children. Three of them are attending school. The eldest was not able to enter college due to the financial burden to sustain her and she was then engaged in an early marriage. 

She wants to continuously provide a good education for the rest of her children, which is why she needs to make her business more profitable.

She is now asking for a loan of PHP 12,000 to buy additional hogs to raise, hog feed and medicines to ensure proper growth and nutrition.

In the future, she wants her children to have a degree and good employment.

loans.use: to buy hogs, feed and medicines.

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
Magdalena is 54 years old and married with three children. She works hard to provide for her family. 
Magdalena runs a sari-sari store in the Philippines and has requested a loan of 18,000 PHP through Kiva partner NWTF to buy items to sell such as shampoo, groceries, etc. in her store.
Magdalena has borrowed and paid back seven loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the sari-sari store for five years and also earns an income from buying and selling rice.
Magdalena aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy items to sell in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more birds for his poultry business

loans.name: Manal

texts.en: Manal is a mother of three sons and one daughter, all under the age of 20. She is a 40-year-old housewife who started a small retail business four years ago to help her husband who works as a taxi driver. Manal basically buys clothes, blankets, and shoes at a wholesale price and re-sells it at a reasonable price. This brought her a lot of customers and made her business grow through the last four years. In order for her to widen her business and reach out to the clothes shops and be their provider, she is thinking of buying a distribution bus that could help her achieve her goal. That’s why she has applied for this loan.

loans.use: To buy a distribution bus

loans.name: Luz

texts.en: Luz is 50 years old and lives in Tinago, Siquijor with her husband and 11 children. She earns about PHP 5,000 a month by raising pigs and is applying for a loan for PHP 8,000 to buy feed and medicine for her animals. She has been a member of the Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for almost a year, and hopes to improve her family's living conditions.

loans.use: to buy feed and medicine for her herd of pigs.

loans.name: Sougrekonta 2 Group

texts.fr:
Mme Rasmata  est la représentante du groupe SOUGREKONTA 2. Elle est mariée  et mère de 04 enfants. Le plus âgé a 32ans et le moins âgé a 20ans. 01 va à l’école. Elle a 03 personnes en charge.

Elle vend des  pagnes, des bijoux, des prêts à porter pour petit et grand depuis plus de 20ans. Elle s’approvisionne à  Lomé au Togo et à Abidjan en Côte d’Ivoire .Ses clients sont les hommes, les femmes et les enfants.

Elle veut  s’acheter  01 balle de pagne, 05 douzaines de bijoux, 05 douzaines de prêt à porter.

 Elle utilise  ses bénéfices pour agrandir  son activité. Elle ambitionne construire une belle maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Rasmata is the representative of the SOUGREKONTA 2 Group.  She is a married mother of four children.  The oldest is 32 years old and the youngest is 20.  One is in school.  She supports three other people

For more than 20 years she has sold pagnes [traditional wraps], jewellery, and ready-to-wear clothing for everyone big to small.  She stocks up in Lomé in Togo and Abidjan in Côte d’Ivoire.  Her customers are men, women, and children alike. 

She would like to purchase one ream of pagnes, five-dozen pieces of jewellery, and five-dozen ready-to-wear items.

She uses her profits to grow her business.  She aspires to build a beautiful house in which to live.

loans.use: To purchase one ream of pagnes, five-dozen pieces of jewellery, and five-dozen pieces of ready-to-wear clothing.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter, a 35-year-old businessman, lives in Juba where he is married and has three children between the ages of eight and three, two of whom go to school. Peter has been operating a mixed food store for six years, and has one employee. His major challenges include competitors and home expenses. Within the next five years, he would like to build his own shop because he is now renting.

Peter, who learned about Finance Sudan through a promotion done by the loan officers, is taking a loan of 1000 SDG to purchase items including sugar, powdered milk, tang juice, and rice. He says that the loan will help his business a great deal, and has an interest rate that is better than other micro-finance institutions.

loans.use: to purchase items like sugar, powdered milk, tang juice, and rice.

loans.name: Rosa Maribel

texts.es:
Rosa, se dedica a vender mariscos, verdura, frutas, ella vive con su esposo y dos hijos, aprendió el trabajo por cuenta propia y lleva ocho años dedicándose a él, han logrado alcanzar experiencia y muchos conocidos dentro del comercio de mariscos.
Actualmente necesita de un préstamo para invertirlo en pescado fresco, camarones, verduras y frutas, además comprará una parte de ropa para la temporada que se acerca con esta inversión podrá fortalecer el negocio e incrementar el inventario de sus productos ofreciéndole a los clientes una mayor variedad y calidad.
La aspiracion de Rosa es comprarse un vehículo a futuro para poder trasladar toda la mercadería hacia el sitio de venta.
texts.en: Rosa sells seafood, vegetables and fruits for a living.  She lives with her husband and two children.  She learned this business on her own and has been doing it for eight years.  She has gained a lot of experience and has many contacts in the seafood business.  Currently, she needs a loan to invest in fresh fish, shrimp, vegetables and fruit.  She will also buy clothing for the coming season.  This investment will strengthen her business and increase her inventory so she can offer her customers more variety and better quality.  Rosa's goal is to buy a vehicle so she can transport her merchandise to the retail site.

loans.use: purchase fresh fish, shrimp, vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Josiane

texts.en:
Josiane is 29 years old. She is married and has two children age 8 months and 2 years old. Neither attends school. 

She has been selling various items for five years. She has requested the loan to buy more items such as rice, potatoes and biscuits. With the profits, she will buy a plot of land for her residence.

loans.use: To buy more rice, potatoes and biscuits to sell.

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua is married and has five children. Ekua  produces palm oil for sale at Ankako, which she has done for four years. Her husband is a carpenter. Ekua uses her income to support her husband in paying their children’s school fees. Ekua will use the loan to buy more palm fruit to produce more palm oil for sale. With the new profit, Ekua will expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more palm fruit to produce more palm oil for sale

loans.name: Ny

texts.en:
Ny (pictured here) and her husband, Sam on, live in a suburb of Phnom Penh City and they have seven children-five sons and two daughters. One is married and lives separately, one is a driver, one is a garment worker, another one workers for a bakery and two attend school and another one is still young. 

Ny sells fish that her husband catches. Her husband is a fisherman and a motor taxi driver. He hopes to change his business from motor taxi driver to remoque driver, because it can carry more goods and people than a motor taxi. Hence Ny decides to ask for a loan of $400 to buy a trailer for her husband. 

A remoque is a motorbike connected with a trailer at the back.

loans.use: To buy a trailer for her husband.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en: Mom is 38 years old. She is a mother of three children and resides with her husband in Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She has been working in a garment factory for more than five years, earning approximately $3 per day. Her husband is a security guard who earns about $3 per day. One of her children is employed as a driver in a company. He earns about $2 per day. In order to improve her family’s finances, Mom is requesting a loan of $1000 to purchase motorbikes to resell. By doing so, she would earn extra income to support the family. In the future, she would like to run a grocery store and help her children earn bachelors' degrees.

loans.use: to purchase motorbikes to resell.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a married man aged 38 years who has three children and has been selling sofa sets for eight years. He operates in a busy area and plans to use the loan to buy materials and timber for making sofa sets. He is faced with the challenge of lack of sufficient funds. The customers are the local residents. John sees himself as having expanded the business in five years time. This is his third loan with SMEP DTM.

loans.use: to buy timber and materials for making sofa sets.

loans.name: Martha

texts.en:
"Hello World!My name is Martha and I live in my farm in Muranga area of Central Kenya with my husband and 3 children all of whom are of school-going age. Farming is my core business where I sell milk, eggs, tea, coffee, and maize. I also have a motorbike which I use to help people and their goods to the local market. My biggest challenge is insufficient money for carrying out her farming activities.

With this loan I will construct a dairy unit which will provide a conducive environment for my animals to feed well and to produce more milk. I will get more income through the sale of more milk and this will enable me to provide more for my family."

loans.use: to construct a zero grazing unit.

loans.name: Omongbé Clotilde

texts.fr: Omongbé Clotilde âgée de 44 ans, a arrêté l’école au niveau primaire.  Omongbé Clotilde est mariée à un décorateur du nom de François. Le couple a trois enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge.  Omongbé Clotilde vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Les diverses charges de la maison sont supportée par le couple.  Pour cette raison, Omongbé Clotilde vend depuis quinze ans, des objets de la quincaillerie comme activité principale. Parallèlement a cette activité, Omongbé Clotilde vend des lubrifiants. Cette activité lui génère des revenus l'aidant à subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.  Omongbé Clotilde achète ses produits dans un marché du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle,  Omongbé Clotilde sollicite pour une quatrième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les prêts antérieurs ont été bien remboursés.

loans.use: Acheter des articles de quincaillerie.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en:
Olive aged 30 years. She is married with 2 children aged 2 and 5 years. Not yet go to school. She is a farmer and she has been growing maize for the past 6 years. Also her husband is a farmer. With the loan from Kiva, she would like to pay workers who harvested maize. The profits from the business will be used to renovate her house and to buy a cow. 

The agriculture sector accounts for 37% of Rwanda's gross domestic product, generates 65% of Rwanda's export revenue, and employs approximately 90% of Rwandans (as of 2009). Despite the importance of agriculture to Rwandans and their economy, financial institutions view lending to fund agricultural activities as a high-risk proposition because the profitability of these activities is affected by weather, natural disasters, and price fluctuations. For this reason, farmers in Rwanda remain underserved by financial institutions. Urwego Opportunity Bank is expanding into this market and is happy to provide Kiva lenders with the opportunity to support Rwandan farmers.

loans.use: To pay workers who harvested maize.

loans.name: Regalada

texts.en:
Regalada is 63 years old and married with five children.

Regalada works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 20,000 loan through GDMPC in order to buy more stocks of groceries to sell.

Regalada has been in this business for 20 years and has previously received funds through Kiva.

Regalada aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks groceries to sell

loans.name: Rashad

texts.en:
27-year old Rashad lives in Salyan region Yenikand village. Rashad is narried, has a child.
He has his own shop. He sells the clothes: jacket, sweater and etc. 
Having borrowed 3 loans of $600-$1000-$1825 from Komak Credit Union he significantly expanded his business. The loans were paid back timely.
Now he needs a loan of $1825 to expand the area of his shop  and to buy new clothes.

loans.use: to expand the area of his business

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Nkaanka Ene Meeli would like to buy 5 steers for fattening.

loans.name: Ecih

texts.en: Ecih  is 39 years old, and is married with four children. They are all boys. To supplement her husband’s income, Ecih  sells porridge from mung beans in front of her house at her small store. In a day Ecih can earn  about  $3 and eventually she can earn around $60 in a month. She needs a loan of $75 and with this loan, she can buy more materials and thus more or less double her income, therefore she can give her children a better life than she grew up with.

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Quy

texts.en:
Quy's family has 3 members who live in the same house with her husband's sister. Her husband grows rice and green dragon plants (for fruit) but he gets low income from his farming venture because of insects.

Quy sells vegetables at a small market. They also raise 30 ducks. Their son (7 years old) attends 2nd grade at school. Their average income is $ 15 per month per person.

Quy wants to borrow $ 50 to increase her business capital. She plans to repay it over the space of 5 months.

loans.use: increase her available capital for her vegetable stand

loans.name: Neang

texts.en:
Mrs. Neang SamB., 50, is married with nine children and lives with her husband (pictured here because Mrs. S. B. was unavailable) in Prey Veng province, Cambodia. She is a street-vendor selling cakes and provisions to the people in her community, and she can typically make $3 each day. Meanwhile, her husband is a cook, earning around $4/day in profit. Three of Neang's children are currently employed at a garment factory, earning together about $150 per month.

During this rainy season, Mrs. Neang S. B. hopes to use the requested loan to purchase a boat with a motor to operate a fishery business. Any remainder of the money will be used to raise pigs, which will enable her to generate additional profits for her household.

loans.use: purchase a boat with a motor to operate a fishery business

loans.name: Sina Tusa

texts.en: Sina is one of the oldest members for of the Samusu village borrowing centre. She is 67 years of age, a widow of 5 children and ten grandchildren. Sina's family used to live in the town but when her husband passed away eight months ago she decided to move to the village where they used to live before. Having a large family was hard especially raising the children and grandchildren. Her children now looking after the plantation, but she decided to do something to occupy her time. This is Sina's first loan and she very delighted with the opportunity given to earn more money to develop her family.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies for her plantation and popcorn/ice-cake business

loans.name: Najjembe Group Loan

texts.en:
You may not think that selling yellow bananas in a country where bananas grow everywhere and cost next to nothing would be a wise business decision, but then you have never seen the sight along the one of a kind roadside venue on the main road from Kenya to Kampala where Nanono is in competition with a least three dozen other women who sell only one thing to passerbys: yellow bananas.

Here’s what happens. There is a constant stream of van taxis each carrying 14 passengers on this very busy and dangerous road. They all stop at this roadside pullover (the driver gets a free bunch of bananas for doing this). Immediately upon stopping, dozens of women attack the van with bunches of ripened bananas. They swarm around every window. The conductor, the man next to the sliding side door, opens it and bunches of banana are pressed into your face. You can buy a ripen bunch, say 14-20 in a bunch for 30 cents. The driver stops long enough to get his free bunch and enough for anyone to buy and off we go again down the road as the ladies back off and wait for the next taxi.

Now get this, Nanono who is 35, single with 6 children and cares for 4 orphans has been doing this for 15 years, supporting her family. She is the chairperson of the Najjembe Lending Group of which she has been a member for the past 7 years. Her portion of the loan will be about $175.00 which she will use to pay school fees for her children.

One side note regarding this group. Loans are disbursed to the group. Although there is not a lot of crime, the time of the loan disbursements can be risky due to the money involved. I asked the group if we could go outside to take the photo and I was told that they were afraid due to the fact that there had been a hold-up a couple of months earlier with another group loan.

loans.use: Nanono plans to use her portion of the group loan to pay her children's school fees.

loans.name: Komlan

texts.fr:
Mr. Kpénou Komlan is 38 years old, married, and has four (04) children who are in school. He has been a scrap iron worker for 6 years. This business provides him with income to meet the daily and educational expenses for his children. This loan will allow him to improve his workshop and to buy raw materials to meet the demands of his clientele.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon

Mr Kpénou Komlan est âgé de 38 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants qui sont à l’école. Il exerce le métier de ferrailleur depuis 6 ans. Cette activité lui procure le revenu pour financer les charges courantes et scolaires de ses enfants. Le présent emprunt lui permet d’améliorer son atelier et d’acheter les matières premières pour la satisfaction de la clientèle

loans.use: To buy raw materials to make metal doors and to improve the workshop

loans.name: Zebonisso.

texts.ru:
Zebonisso S., 41, is married and has 3 children. Zebonisso has a college degree. She lives in the town of Vakhdat where she teaches at the local secondary school. Zebonisso wants to take this loan to purchase a milk cow to provide milk for her family. Zebonisso plans to repay this loan within 12 months.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Шерова Зебониссо проживает в городе Вахдат. Возраст 41 год, замужем имеет 3 детей. Образование высшее. Работает учителем в средней школе.Хочет получить кредит для приобретения дойной коровы, чтобы обеспечит семью молоком. Погасить кредит клиентка планирует в течении 12 месяцев.

loans.use: To purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Yabteclum 3 Group

texts.es:
Carmela is 36 years old and is dedicated to the sale of cut-up chickens. In order to buy her chickens, she must travel to the Municipal Capital and keep them in her patio at home. Sales are low because meat is hardly consumed due to its elevated price. People in the community feed off their crops (corn, beans, and vegetables). With the small profit she makes, Carmela purchases more chickens and maintains five children. With your credit she wants to buy more chickens and a new scale. The other members of the group are: Maria G., who sells beans, corn, and is a craftswoman; Araceli De Jesus P. S., who owns a grocery store; Carmen P. R., who sells lollipops, pens, and cold beverages; and Lucia P. G., who is also a craftswoman.

Carmela de 36 años de edad, se dedica a la venta de pollo trozado, tiene que viajar a la cabecera municipal para comprar sus pollos y mantenerlos en patio de su casa, su venta es poca ya que en la comunidad casi nunca se consume carne por lo caro, la gente se alimenta de sus cosechas, (maíz, frijoles y verduras) que ellos mismos producen, con la poca ganancia que obtiene compra mas pollos y mantiene a 5 hijos, con su crédito ella quiere comprar mas pollos y una pesa nueva, las otras integrantes del grupo son: María Guzmán Pérez vende frijoles y maíz y es artesana, Araceli De Jesús Pérez S. tienda de abarrotes, Carmen Pérez R., vende paletas, bolis y refrescos fríos y Lucia Pérez Gutiérrez es artesana.

Translated to English by Patricia Yáñez, Kiva volunteer.

loans.use: To purchase chickens and a scale.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is 29 years old and is married woman with 1child, age 9 years old. She and her husband also take care of 1 other child, age 19 years old. Fatuma is a food seller, she started in 2008. Everyday, she works from 6am to 8pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about $50 from her sales.

She now hopes for a loan to buy more fish for her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish for her business.

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
My house is missing a fence around it and in the back. But, at this moment I do not have the money necessary to buy the materials . For this reason, I am requesting a loan of $1000 in order to buy the materials to build a fence for the security of my house and kids.

This story has been translated from Spanish to English by Nikita Ramchandani, KIVA Volunteer.

A mi casa le esta haciendo falta las barda al rededor y los acabados del exterior. Pero por el momento no tengo el monto que necesito para comprar el material es por eso que solicito un préstamo de $1,000.00 dlls. Para la compra del material de la barda y que así este mas segura la casa y mis hijos.

loans.use: To build a fence around the house

loans.name: Sadullo

texts.ru:
Sadullo N. is married and has 5 children. He works at the regional market. He has a place where he sells building materials. He is a retail salesman. Now is the season when demand is high, and Sadullo needs to be able to buy more goods by obtaining a loan. This will help attract new clients and bring additional profit, which his family needs. To achieve his goal, Sadullo needs to obtain a loan. He plans to repay it within 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Startseva, Kiva volunteer.

Нарзуллоев Саъдулло женат, имеет пятерых детей. Работает на рынке района . Имеет торговую точку, где торгует стройматериалами. Продает в розницу. Но в сезон продаж ему необходимо увеличить товарооборот, путем получения кредита. Это поможет ему привлечь новых клиентов и принесет дополнительный доход, необходимый его семье. Для достижения цели он должен получить кредит, а погасить его в течении 18 месяцев.

loans.use: To increase variety of goods

loans.name: Thérèse

texts.fr:
Thérèse S., 35, is a widow raising 2 children. She has been a member of the village bank of Kadior for two years. She intends to invest her loan in selling cosmetics (perfumes, deodorants, bath gels, body lotions, etc.) in a conveniently located canteen in town to bolster her business. Her income will allow her to contribute to daily expenses and improve living conditions for her family. She is requesting a loan that will be reimbursed at the end of six months in one single repayment.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Thérèse S., 35 ans, veuve, 02 enfants en charge est membre du banc villageois de Kadior depuis 2 ans. Elle compte investir son prêt dans la vente de produits cosmétiques (parfums, déodorants, gels de bain, crèmes pour le corps etc…) dans une cantine bien placée en ville pour renforcer son commerce. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer à la dépense quotidienne et d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille. Elle sollicite un prêt qui sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.

loans.use:
Purchase of cosmetics to be sold in a canteen

Achat de produits cosmétiques à vendre dans une cantine

loans.name: Marame

texts.fr:
Marame M. is a young unmarried woman born in 1979. She works in a non-governmental organization in Thiès. In parallel with this job, she also raises poultry. Her business consists of buying chicks, which she raises over several weeks before re-selling them to her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

Marame M. est une jeune célibataire née en 1979.elle travaille dans une organisation non gouvernementale à THIES ;parallèlement elle fait de l'aviculture .son activité consiste à acheter des poussins qu'elle élève pendant quelques semaines avant de les revendre à ses clients.

loans.use: To raise poultry

loans.name: Thi Thoi

texts.vi: Chị Thơi  tham gia vào Quỹ từ năm 2007. Hàng ngày chồng chị đi làm thuê cho đại lý thu mua lợn tại địa phương cho thu nhập từ  2 đến 3 triệu đồng/ tháng còn chị ở nhà chăn nuôi  gần 200 con gà  và chăm sóc hai con còn nhỏ. Với mong muốn cuộc sống gia đình ngày càng được cải thiện  thu nhập của gia đình ngày càng tăng lên, thời gian tới gia đình chị có kế hoạch đầu tư sửa sang chuồng trại và đầu tư mua thêm lợn giống về nuôi.  Mức vốn xin vay 9.000.000đ
texts.en:
Mrs. Thoi has joined the TYM Fund since 2007. Her husband is a hired worker for the pig retailing store in the village, earning 2 million to 3 million VND (about 125USD to 187USD) each month. Mrs. Thoi stays at home to raise 200 chickens and take care of her two young children. Wanting to improve the standard of living and increase her family's income, she is planning to invest in renovating the chicken coop and purchasing breeding pigs. She would like to borrow 9,000,000VND (550USD).

Translated from Vietnamese by Yen Thanh Pham, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying pigs

loans.name: Faauma

texts.en:
Faauma A. F., 54, is married with 7 children. She has many years of experience in the cabbages, cucumbers, tomatoes and pumpkins business. She sells to the villages and the public 3 days per week. She has 4 previous loans with SPBD. She expects her weekly net cash flow to be 500 Tala (~208 USD).

SPBD loans are Faauma's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with the traditional banks. Her loan will be used to buy a sack of fertilizers, vegetable seeds, a spade, a shovel and a knife for her vegetable business. Her husband helps her in operating the business.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, vegetable seeds, spade, shovel and knife

loans.name: Doris

texts.en:
Doris Y. is married and has 3 children and has no formal education. Doris sells yams to local consumers at Prasu market in Elmina, which she has done since 1998.

Doris' husband is a preacher. She uses her income to help him pay school fees and utility bills. Doris will use the loan ($625.00) to purchase more yams for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Doris plans to further her children's education.

loans.use: Purchase more yams for sale

loans.name: Mrs. Mach Soun Village Bank Group

texts.en:
Nine people who live in Kandal Lue Village in Kandal Province have applied for a group loan that they will use for different purposes. Mrs. Mach S. is requesting a loan to buy fertilizer to improve the productivity of her field. Her husband, Mr. Yong Yeth, helps her on her farm. They have fO. children who are all attending the local school.

This request consists of two end-of-term loans, with the rest being monthly payment loans. The two borrowers with end-of-term loans are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. These loans are AMK’s main product because they are most beneficial to Cambodia’s poor. These loans allow them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK’s clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva loans.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer

loans.name: Theresa

texts.en:
Theresa C. sells fish. She buys them directly from the fishermen, brings them home for processing and preservation, and then sends them to the market for resale. She also sells gari, a cassava-based fritter. She buys sacks of freshly milled  cassava and extracts the starch from the cassava dough. She then fries the cassava dough to make the gari. Her business is located at Elmina. Theresa has been selling fish and making gari since 2002.

Theresa has a basic education.  She is married and has 4 dependents.  Her husband is a fisherman.  She helps her husband take care of the children's needs and meet other financial obligations. She will use her loan  to buy fresh fish for processing and also cassava for gari. She hopes to use the profits from her business to put her children through school.

She is shown with some sacks of milled cassava yet to be processed into gari.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish and cassava

loans.name: Veang

texts.en: Veang R., 58, is an old mother who resides in the province of Siem Reap. Her husband, Seak Thy, 60, pictured here, is a rice farmer and makes less than one dollar each day. This couple has four children, two of whom are employed as construction workers. They always provide money to help raise their standard of living. Veang R. would like to take out a loan of US$700 to purchase fertilizers and rice seed for her husband’s farm.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and rice seed.

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en:
Joyce N., a widow, is one of the executive members of Kewerimidde group, working as the payments’ controller. She is a strong, hard-working lady, managing all manly duties like fishing using her late husband’s 3 boats and it is a paying job except that these days the fish are not easy to come by.

Joyce is also a farmer with various food plantations for both home consumption and for sale; she also has 3 Fresian cows at home for milk and she has a ready market for that milk with her daughter, in S.6 vacation, managing the sales. Joyce's husband's passing left her to provide for 10 kids, and one of her greatest achievements is being able to educate her children with no one below the level of S.6. Joyce needs a loan to help with buying fishing nets and employing labor on her farm for fast and high quality yields.

loans.use: Buying fishing nets and employing labor on her farm.

loans.name: Facunda

texts.es:
Facunda trabaja como artesana y confecciona polleras para damas que  comercializa en las ferias populares de la ciudad de el Alto siendo esta actividad su principal fuente de ingreso con  que cubre la manutención de un hija de esta estudiando en la universidad publica de El Alto; vive en alquiler ubicado en la zona Loreto de la misma Ciudad.

El crédito lo destinara para la compra de materia prima (tela) de esa forma podrá satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por la prestataria.
texts.en:
Facunda works as an artisan, making traditional skirts for women and selling them in the El Alto's markets. This is her principal source of income, which she uses to pay rent for her house in the neighbourhood of Loreto and also, to support her daughter, who is in university. She will use this loan to buy cloth so that she can meet the demand that exists for her products. This is her first loan from Impro, but she has been fully evaluated as a potential client and deemed eligible to receive the loan she has requested.

Translated from Spanish by Sara Sultan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cloth

loans.name: Placida

texts.es: La Señora Placida P. M. tiene 46 años de edad, su estado civil es casada. Doña Placida tiene 3 hijos y todos sus hijos trabajan de manera independiente. La actividad económica de Doña Placida es los servicios de costura. Hace mas de 17 años que se dedica a este negocio Doña Placida inicio con capital propio por lo que poco a poco invirtió en su negocio y hasta los momentos ha logrado mantenerlo activo. Los propósitos de Doña Placida son de invertir lo suficiente para seguir con su negocio. El financiamiento es para capital de trabajo ya que necesita realizar la inversión en materia prima como tela, hilos y otros artículos. Los sueños de Doña Placida son que su negocio obtenga una buena fama por vender productos de calidad. La cantidad que solicita es de C$ 12.000 córdobas.
texts.en:
Mrs. Placida P. M. is 46 years old. She is married and has 3 children. All of her children work independently. For more than 17 years Placida has worked as a seamstress. She started with her own money, and little by little, she invested in the business. Up until now she has been able to maintain her business. Placida would like to invest enough money to keep running her business. The loan is for working capital. She needs to buy materials like fabric, thread and other things. Placida’s dream is that her business gets a good reputation for selling quality products. She is asking for $625.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Bashiran Abid Hussain Group

texts.en:
Bashiran baji is 34 years old and resides in a mid-size city named Vehari, Pakistan. She has been a part of this city for the past 20 years. She successfully repaid her four previous loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a fifth loan, for her husband’s fruit-selling business.

Her husband has 3 years of experience in this business. He goes to different areas of the community and sells his products by announcing them in a loud voice. Bashiran baji is a very hard-working lady. She shares the financial burden of her husband by sewing clothes.

Bashiran baji is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Siddiqan baji, Sakina bji, and N. baji each want a loan to buy groceries for their grocery shops. Tasleem baji wants a loan to buy seasonal fruits to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy seasonal fruits to sell

loans.name: Santos Daniel

texts.es: Santos Daniel es de la comunidad de Poxlajuj del departamento de Totonicapan desde niño aprendio el arte de la tejeduria siendo operario, hace diez años puso su propio Negocio  con su pequeño taller y con dos operarios  en la elaboracion de manteles y chalinas  que las entregava en la ciudad de Guatemala, hoy en dia esta  elaborando cortes tipicos especialemte para damas ya que la entrega en Salcaja Quetzaltenango y otros pueblos hoy necesita de un credito para surtir sus materiales.
texts.en:
Santos Daniel is from the Poxlajuj community in the state of Totonicapan. When he was a child he learned how to weave, operating a weaving machine. 10 years ago he opened his own business with a small shop and two employees, making tablecloths and shawls that he delivers to Guatemala City. Today he is making traditional skirts for women for delivery in Salcaja Quetzaltenango and other towns. Today he needs a loan to stock his supplies.

Translated from Spanish by Cindy Kendall, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Saida

texts.ru: Саида Тагоймуродова проживает в районе Рудаки. В возрасте 51 года. Замужем, имеет 3 детей. Саида занимается пошивом одеяла и его продажей. У нее имеются постоянные покупатели, которые торгуют на рынке. Этим видом бизнеса занимается более 22 лет. Муж находится на заработках в России. Клиенка хочет взять у нас кредит, чтобы увеличить объем продажи.
texts.en:
Saida T. lives in the Rudaki region. She is 51 years old. She is married and has 3 children. Saida makes and sells quilts. She has regular customers who sell at the market. She has been in this business for more than 22 years. Her husband is earning money in Russia. The client would like to get credit in order to increase her sales.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase sales

loans.name: 7 De Julio Group

texts.es: Las socias del banco comunal "7 D. julio",  no presentan ningún nexo consanguíneo  ni D. afinidad. Las socias desarrollan diferentes actividades comerciales y D. servicio por el barrio la pajonal tales como vendedoras cosméticos ambulantes, tienda D. abarrotes y los socios participantes con el transporte público D. pasajeros, vendedores D. tarjetas telefónicas. En cuanto a la competencia se pueD. decir que ellos están conscientes D. la misma pero saben como salir adelante en especial si se cuenta con la confianza D. una institución que siempre esta dispuesta a extender una ayuda para que los socios puedan sacar adelante sus negocios con la compra D. materiales, insumo y herramientas que generen mayores ingresos y mejore la calidad D. vida D. sus familias. Un porcentaje alto D. las socias ya cuentan con experiencia ya que trabajaron con grupos anteriores en la Fundación Agrocapital por lo que conocen la modalidad des trabajo solidario así como la responsabilidad que se requiere para formar parte D. un grupo.
texts.en:
The members of the "7 D. Julio" (July 7th) Village Bank are neither related to each other nor have anything in common. They engage in a variety of commercial and service activities in the El Pajonal neighborhood. The women's businesses incluD. traveling cosmetics sales, and a grocery store, and the men's incluD. public transportation services, and phone card sales. The members are aware that there is competition. They know how to get ahead, though, especially when they have the trust of an organization that is always inclined to help its members buy materials, supplies, and tools so their businesses can generate more income and their families can enjoy a better quality of life. A large proportion of the members have prior experience working with Fundación Agrocapital so they know how to work alone as well as the responsibility required to be part of a group.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Abdukodir

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 

Тошматов Абдукодир  - мужчина 1958-го года рождения , женат,  имеет 4-х  детей.  У Абдукодира высшее образование , он работает директором ТВ «Гулякандоз».Но этого не хватает чтобы   прокормить  его большую семью.Поэтому он  решил  заняться  откормом  скота.  Абдукодир   имеет  большой  опыт  в  сфере  животноводства,  так  как    с  юных  лет  помогал  отцу  пасти  скот.  Абдукодиру помогают  его  сыновья.  Он  закупает  бычков  на Джаббор-Расуловском   скотном  рынке  и,  откормив  в  течении  5-6  месяцев,  перепродаёт  их  за  хорошую  цену.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. Abdukodir T. is a man born in 1958, married and has four children. Abdukodir has higher education and works as a director on TV Gulyakandoz. But it is not enough to feed his big family. This is why he decided to start raising cattle. Abdukodir has a great experience in the field of animal husbandry because since his young years he was helping his father to shepherd the cattle. Abdukodir's sons also help him. He buys calves on the Jabbor-Rasulov cattle market and after feeding them for five to six months he resells them for a better price.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es: Margarita tiene 49 años, es una madre muy amorosa y trabajadora, vive en su propia casa junto a sus 3 hijos Ruth de 15, Tony de 14 y Juan de 10 años. Ellos son el motivo de todos sus esfuerzos y desea darles unos buenos estudios superiores. Al restaurante de Margarita lo que menos le faltan son clientes, puesto que está ubicado cerca al terminal de la línea de transportes urbana Nº 15. Sus principales comensales son los chóferes y cobradores, quienes luego de una larga mañana de trabajo, no dudan en degustar los deliciosos platos que ella prepara. Los precios que ofrece Margarita a sus clientes son muy accesibles y este es el principal gancho de su restaurante, lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es cocinas y ver como las personas alaban su buena sazón. Lleva 7 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es atender a todos sus clientes y mantenerlos satisfechos. Margarita espera que en el futuro su restaurante se convierta en uno de los más conocidos de la ciudad de Juliaca, sabe que para alcanzar sus metas tiene que trabajar muy duro y está dispuesta a hacerlo. Este es su quinto préstamo con MFP y al igual como hizo con sus primeros créditos, pagará todas sus cuotas a tiempo. En su banco comunal es una socia muy querida y respetada por la responsabilidad que demuestra. Con los mil nuevos soles solicitados comprará más sillas y mesas para mejorar la atención en su restaurante.
texts.en:
Margarita, 49, is a very loving and hard working mother. She lives in her own house with her three children; Ruth is 15, Tony is 14, and Juan is 10. They are the motivation for all of her efforts. She wishes to give them a good high school education. What Margarita’s restaurant lacks the least is customers, given that it is located near the terminal to the urban transportation line N° 15. Her primary customers are the drivers and the collectors who, after a long morning of work, do not hesitate to enjoy the delicious dishes that she prepares. Margarita’s prices are very reasonable, and they are the primary attraction to her restaurant. What she likes most about her work is cooking and seeing how the people praise her good seasoning. She has been doing this for seven years. The most difficult part is waiting on customers and keeping them satisfied. In the future, Margarita hopes to make her restaurant one of the most well known in the city of Juliaca. She knows that she must work very hard to achieve her goals, and she is prepared to do so. This is her fifth loan with MFP. Just as she did with her first loans, she will make all of her payments on time. She is well liked and respected in her community bank for the responsibility that she demonstrates. She will use the 1,000 PEN that she is asking for to buy more chairs and tables to improve customer service in her restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy furniture for her restaurant

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina is a member of the Mgodi West borrower group in Kinyanambo, Iringa. She is 32 years old, married, and the mother of 4 children. Her children are aged 14, 13, 8, and 1 years old.

Penina started her own business selling electric tools four years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Penina’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more goods. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Penina hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more eletrical goods

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce P. is married to an electrician and has four dependents. She is responsible for assisting her husband to take good care of her children. Joyce has received junior high school education. Since 2005 she has run a small boutique at Essuman, near Secondi, where she sells clothes. She will use her loan to expand her business by buying a greater variety of clothing for resale. Joyce hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into the business.

loans.use: To purchase a greater variety of clothing for resale

loans.name: Argelia Belen

texts.es: Argelia Belén Sánchez Martínez tiene 1 hijo se dedica a la compra-venta de ropa en general, ella ha logrado obtener clientes fijos desde que inicio su negocio y esto le ha permitido obtener ganancias que le han ayudado a solventar gastos en su hogar pues ella es madre y padre para su hijo. Hasta la fecha doña Argelia ha estado trabajando con financiamientos de Fundación León 2000 y nuevamente hoy recurre a esta organización con la necesidad de un financiamiento que le permita comprar ciertos artículos como: trajes para niños, jóvenes, adultos y ancianos. Su deseo es aumentar cada día en su inventario para satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Argelia Belén Sánchez Martínez has one child. She buys and sells clothing and has managed to secure regular customers since she began her business. Her profits have enabled her to meet her household expenses since she has to be both mother and father to her son.

Doña Argelia has been working with loans through Fundación León 2000 and has returned to the organization for another request. She needs financing to purchase certain items such as clothing for children, teenagers, adults, and the elderly. She hopes to increase her inventory every day so that she can meet the demand of her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital

loans.name: Hadijah's Group

texts.en: N. Hadijah is the leader of her lending group in Lugazi. She is 58 years old and a widow with 5 children all in primary and secondary school as well as taking care of other orphans. She is a business lady involved in the sale of agricultural produce from Buikwe trading centre for 7 years. Her major business challenge is having a lot of competition among people in the same business hence reducing the prices. She started with the sale of clothes and changed for the better and is not regretting. She hopes to become a wholesale supplier of agricultural produce so that she can be able to earn much. She needs a loan to help buy more agricultural produce for resale since this widens her profits and enables the payment of school fees. She is such a hard working lady.

loans.use: Buying more agricultural produce for resale.

loans.name: Florigen

texts.en:
Florigen N. lives in the village of Pasil, Brgy. Tagda, Hinigaran Negros Occidental. She is 45 years old, married to Felomino N. who helps in running their businesses, and is blessed to have four young adult children. The youngest is 19 years old and the oldest is 26, and all of them help in the business for which Florigen pays them compensation. 

Because of her desire to help her husband support their family, Florigen joined NWTF-Project Dungganon to access capital that no one would have loaned to her without any collateral. When she received her first loan, she invested it by starting a mobile fish business. She would go from town to town selling fish during the town's market day, and she reinvested most of her income back into the business to gradually increase her stock volume. She used some of the income to send her children to school, but when they graduated from High School, they did not want to go to college and instead started helping with the business. With more helpers in her business, she expanded her operations to include selling dried fish, buying stocks from other suppliers. If any of her fresh fish stock was not sold, she sun dried them also so they wouldn't spoil, and would still earn a profit. 

Because of her good customer service, she was able to develop a good relationship with a regular customer who orders dried fish in bulk from her, and she now regularly sends a box of dried fish to Manila twice a week. Aside from her fresh and dried fish business, she also sells different varieties of bananas, and also has a pig fattening venture. From these different business activities, she earns PHP 10,000 a month net income and it helps pay for the household expenses, with some left over for reinvestment in the business and savings.  

Her previous loan of PHP 29,000 was used as working capital for her businesses. She was able to pay her loan on time without any delays. This contributed to her good credit performance as a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon, and she was able to access a bigger loan for her next cycle. Now she is borrowing for her 16th cycle PHP 35,000 to add to her capital in the mobile fish store and pig fattening business, so that she can provide a better future of her family.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital for her fish business and pig fattening business

loans.name: Huk

texts.en:
Huk Y., 63, is married and resides with her husband (pictured) in Sa Ang, Cambodia. She lives with one of her children who is married and employed in a local garment factory, earning an income of US$3 per day.

Y. is a housewife who takes care of the household chores while her husband is a motorbike repairman at a local market. Her husband is able to generate an income of approximately US$5 per day as their primary source of income for the family.

This couple is seeking to expand the husband’s current business and thus to improve their family’s standard of living. Therefore, Y. is asking for a loan of US$300 for her husband to purchase motorbike spare parts to meet his customers’ needs when their motorbikes break down.

loans.use: To buy motorbike spare parts for her husband's business

loans.name: Estella

texts.en:
Estella H. is single. She is now 56 years old and still fighting against the poverty that has been her experience. She has no family but is still working hard for herself and also for others that need her help.

The main source of Estella’s income comes from her variety store that she has run for thirty-one years now. For that long a time she has done everything to make this business grow and continue to run because, aside from the fact that it gives her income to sustain to her daily expenses, it became her partner in entertaining herself through the people that she encounters while selling her items.

When Estella became a member of Kiva field partner Ahon sa Hirap Inc. (ASHI), aside from the capital that she gets from this institution, she also found her second family in the presence of other members. That is why she is enjoying being a part of it. Now, her 11th loan will be used as additional capital for her variety store business. She will buy different groceries and many other items that are needed by her store.

Estella says she is working hard, not only for herself to have a better life but also to help others in their needs. She is just hoping to have a long life so that she can do this.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her variety store

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To equip his workshop, buy lumber and work tool

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
This is Zainab K.. She is a 30-year-old married woman from Tombo town in Waterloo. She has one child, a girl.

Zainab has been a LAPOSL client for some time now, and has taken two previous loans. She is a member of a LAPOSL union (a credit group that acts as a collective collateral and guarantor). This is the first loan she will be receiving with the help of Kiva lenders.

Zainab sells clothing in Tombo park including baby wear and undergarments as well as cloth goods such as handkerchiefs and wraps. With her previous loans she expanded her business by purchasing extra inventory. With her new loan she hopes to add more goods to her business.

Zainab would like to take the additional profit from her increased business and open a savings account at the bank.

loans.use: To purchase more baby wear, brassieres, and cloth goods

loans.name: Mtama Kulanga Group

texts.en:
Tatu M. is a widow with two children, aged 14 and 10.  She has a business selling vegetables, fruits, water, juice, cooking oil and paraffin.  She has been in this business for six months now, and works from 8 am until 8 pm every day. Tatu manages to make a monthly profit of around $91.  She hopes for a loan to buy a weighing machine so she can start selling sugar, wheat flour and rice.  This will be her first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.

Tatu will share this loan with her loan group,  Mtama Kulanga,. The group has 18 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, Tatu is in the first row, third from the left, in the corner wearing a head cover.

loans.use: to buy a weighing machine so she can start selling sugar, rice and wheat flour

loans.name: Ros

texts.en: Ros C., 25, is a young married lady and a hard working woman who resides in Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia. She is married with a child who is a minor and not enrolled in school. Her husband, Vanna, 25, is with her in the photo. He works as a staff member for a transportation company. To earn an income to help cover the family's daily needs, Ros C. owns a grocery shop inside the Chom Puvan market where she sells a variety of cooking ingredients. She is able to generate a daily income of $5 a day, which she uses to feed her family, especially her child. Ros C. needs a loan to buy a motorcycle to use as transportation and she intends to use any money remaining from the loan to increase the financial capital of her grocery sale business.

loans.use: To buy a motorcycle and to increase her financial capital

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en: The two persons shown in the picture are Mrs. Chhorn P., 48, and her husband, age 42. They currently live in Siem Reap Province. Chhorn P. earns a living by raising pigs in a pigpen behind her house. She raises them both for their offspring and for slaughter. In addition, she also cultivates a rice crop, while her husband is a rice farmer and also a firewood seller. They have two school-aged children. Chhorn P. will use her loan to grow rice.

loans.use: To grow rice.

loans.name: Elena

texts.en:
Elena M. is from the village of Cabisera 17-21. She is 56 years old. Elena is married with children. Elena owns & operates a livestock business, primarily rearing pigs for sale. Elena has been engaged in her business for over 2 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP whenever she sells an animal.

In 2010, Elena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Elena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elena from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell

loans.name: Venant

texts.en:
Venant is 34 years old, married with one child who is 14 years old.  Venant and his small family live in the Kicukiro district, one of the districts of Kigali, the capital city of Rwanda.  Venant has been selling a variety of clothing styles since 2008 and the hours of his business are from 7 AM to 5 PM every day.

Venant needs to request a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company for the purpose of purchasing many trousers and women's clothes, as they are highly demanded in his business.  With this loan, Venant hopes to increase his sales as well as his profits.  Those profits will be used in the further reinvestment of his business as well as taking care of his family.

loans.use: Addtional clothes for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase sodas in large quantities for his restaurant, as well as make improvements.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
Marilyn Y. lives in the town of Brgy Sagasa, Ma-ao, Bago City.  She is married and has three children, ages 13 to 28.  To make a living, Marilyn owns & operates a 'sari sari' (variety) store.  The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community.  Marilyn has been engaged in this business for several years and earns approximately 12,000 Php a month from these activities.  The store is conveniently located on the side of a road traveled by tricycles (local three-wheeled transport vehicles) and school children alike.  She also has a small 1.25 hectare plot of land on which she plants rice.  

Marilyn joined NWTF to gain access to financial services to help improve  her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Marilyn has successfully repaid a previous loan from NWTF. Marilyn is now requesting a new loan of 12,000 Php which will be used to purchase additional products to sell.  This will be the 6th loan taken out by the borrower from NWTF.  Marilyn plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business  to pay the tuition fee of her youngest child, who is in first year high school.

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon."

loans.use: Additional capital for her 'sari sari' store

loans.name: Luy

texts.en:
Mrs. Luy P., 67, sells grilled bananas to earn a living and lives with her husband and four children who are students. From her business she is able to generate $5 each day to cover the financial problems of her family. One of her kids is working as a chef for weddings.

Luy P.’s husband, Mr. Moul Phat, is a fish-seller who goes to buy the fish from his wholesale suppliers who are fishermen at the river. Her husband complains he always pays a lot of money for fish delivery fees and has a goal to have a vehicle so that he can cut down on hiring fees.

Therefore, Luy P. requests a loan to add to her savings to buy a motorbike for her husband to pick up the fish from the river to sell at the market.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her husband's fish-selling business

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita S. is from the village of Minsapinit, Gingoog City. She is 55 years old and widowed. Teresita owns and operates a specialized retail store selling flowers in the local community. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2009, Teresita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more copra to sell. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Teresita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more copra to sell

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en:
Ibrahim is a 33-year-old married man from Lebanon. He lives with his wife and 5 children. He runs a business installing and replacing floor tiles. He has been involved in this field for almost 18 years. His customers include local community members. He notes that difficulty in finding sufficient financing for his business has been a challenge. He also says that it is a challenge to find new and better ways of advertising his work. He is proud of his extensive experience and high quality work.

He is requesting a loan of 2,000,000 Lebanese pounds from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to use this loan to invest in new tools and transportation for his business. This will be his first loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To invest in new tools and transportation for his business.

loans.name: Jeffrey

texts.en: Jeffrey G. is from Barangay Tucal, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. He is 25 years old, is married, and has two infant children. Jeffrey owns and operates a business raising pigs for breeding. He has been engaged in his business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month. In 2009, Jeffrey joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase breeding livestock. Jeffrey is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be his second from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is married with four children, who all attend school. She also takes care of her young brothers and sisters because her parents have died. She resides in and owns a two room house and the family has no access to electricity and piped water.

For the past five years, Sarah has had a business selling tomatoes, onions, oranges and mangoes from a stall that she owns. Her customers are people in the nearby community. She works six days a week and sells at both the retail and wholesale levels. She wants to use this loan to buy more boxes of tomatoes, oranges, onions and mangoes. Sarah's business challenges are perishability and transportation. She hopes to own a freezer. She joined MCDT to get additional capital.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes, onions, mangoes and oranges

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda is 46 years old and married with three children. She lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.

To supply additional income for her family, Yolanda is starting a hog-fattening business. She is motivated and determined to launch a successful business endeavor of her own.

Yolanda would like to receive a loan to purchase feeds and vitamins for her hogs. As a member of Ahon sa Hirap, Inc. (ASHI), a Kiva micro-finance partner in the Philippines, Yolanda is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams.

Yolanda’s longterm goals are to build a sustainable business, to fund her children’s college education, and for her family to have their own car. With the support of Kiva lenders, Yolanda is positive that her business will generate sound profits to improve her financial stability and her family’s quality of living.

loans.use: To purchase feeds and vitamins for her hogs

loans.name: Roxana

texts.es: Roxana tiene 29 años, vive junto a su esposo y dos pequeños hijos en su casa propia. Hace más de 5 años vende ropa, considerándolo como un trabajo muy rentable,  pues consigue su mercadería a precio al por mayor y de ahí lo vende a un precio conveniente para que aumente sus ganancias. De esta manera Roxana visita a sus amigas ofreciendo la prendas que vende y al cabo de un tiempo esta recibiendo el pago de dicho producto. Le gusta mucho su trabajo pues ha ganado muchas amistades en el trascurso del tiempo, además es muy conocida por su vecindario por sus buenas ofertas y variedad de mercadería que ofrece. Solo espera mas adelante consolidar un negocio más grande, pero sabe que aún necesita juntar capital para conseguirlo. Este es su segundo crédito con MFP y se compromete a ser muy puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el crédito que solicita, desea comprar mayor cantidad de prendas de vestir y así aumentar sus ventas.
texts.en:
Roxana is 29 years old and lives with her husband and two small children in the family's own house. For more than 5 years, she has sold clothing, finding it a quite profitable business. She obtains her merchandise wholesale and sells it at a convenient price that provides her with increased profits. Roxana visits her friends and offers the garments she sells, and after a while she receives payment for her products. She enjoys her work very much, because she has made many friends over the course of time. She is also well-known among her neighbors for her good prices and the variety of merchandise she offers. Her hope for the future is to establish a larger business, but she knows that she still needs to save up the capital to achieve this. This is her second loan with MFP, and she is committed to being very punctual with all of her payments. With the loan she is requesting, she wants to buy a larger quantity of garments so that she can increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Expanding her stock of garments

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase basic grains, soft drinks, vegetables, snacks etc.

loans.name: Azeezan

texts.en:
Azeezan lives in a small city called Raiwind, located in the Punjab province of Pakistan. She lives in a three-room brick house in the area of Ghouspura where she moved with her family nine years ago. She is 44 years of age and the mother of six children. Her elder sons have left their education and are currently working. One is an employee in the factory and other works in a church. Her younger children are attending school and getting their education.

Azeezan’s husband works in the factory and, after his day job, he operates a grocery shop in the market. Azeezan stays at home and takes care of her family and her cattle (cows and buffalos). She gets milk from her cattle and sells it in her community to support her family financially. She has been doing this work for the past three years.

The members of Azeezan’s family respect her for her supportive nature. She has applied for a loan from Asasah for her husband who wants to buy groceries for his grocery shop. She is hopeful that this investment will help her husband to improve his business to a satisfactory level.

Azeezan is a regular loan user of Asasah and is on her 3rd loan. In her previous years of loan experience she has proved herself to be a responsible client who never missed a single meeting and paid her installments on time.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for her husband's grocery store

loans.name: Chin

texts.en:
Mrs. Chin C. is an old woman whose husband appears on the photograph above. Sewing clothes is the main part of 45-year-old Mrs. Chin C.’s daily duty at the garment industry. She has been engaged in her job since 2000 and has a steady salary. She has a life partner in her husband who works as a construction foreman. The couple helps each other to earn money to feed their three kids. All three of the kids are attending school. 

Chin C. also buys clothes that are not export quality from her garment factory to resell in her community. In order to generate additional income for the family, Chin C. is taking out her loan as capital to buy a larger quantity of clothes from the garment industry to resell, which will allow her to improve her profit.

loans.use: To buy a larger quantity of clothing from the garment industry to resell

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en: Carlito D. is from the village of Siempre Viva Norte. He is 35 years old. Carlito is married and has an infant child. To make a living, Carlito runs a general store. The main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Carlito has been engaged in his business for over four years and earns approximately 3,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from it. In 2008, Carlito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Carlito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items to expand his product offering. Carlito is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the fourth loan taken out by Carlito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Eric

texts.en:
Eric E., 31 years old, is a rice farmer and a food vendor. He has been working his farm for five years now. The income he is able to generate from his farm enables him to buy basic necessities for his family. While most of his rice harvest goes toward the family’s daily consumption, he also sells some of the harvest to earn money for his family.

Eric would like to apply for a loan with Community Economic Ventures Inc. in order to buy three sacks of seed and five sacks of fertilizer. He likes CEVI’s services because they include micro-insurance products in their loans.

loans.use: To buy three sacks of seed and five sacks of fertilizer

loans.name: Norma Deysi

texts.es:
Norma de 55 años, tiene una pequeña tienda en la parte delantera de su casa. Vive en Orquídeas de Guayaquil (zona urbana, llamada las orquídeas porque en su descubrimiento habían muchas flores orquídeas).

El interés de ella tener una tienda fue para poder solventar los gastos de su hijo, poco a poco fue surtiendo su tienda hasta que fue conocida por la gente del sector donde vivía, en la actualidad trabaja desde las 07h00am hasta las 22h00pm todo los días. Vende arroz, aceite, carnes, bebidas etc. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar arroz, azúcar y bebidas para poder aumentar su tienda. En el futuro quiere que su negocio se incremente para tener mas ingresos y asegurar la vida de su familia.
texts.en:
Norma is 55 years old and has a little store in the front part of her house. She lives in Las Orquídeas de Guayaquil (an urban zone called "The Orchids" because when it was first settled, there were many orchid flowers in the area). 

Her interest in having a store arose because she wanted to cover the expenses of her son. Little by little, she expanded the stock of her store until it became well-known among the people in the area where she lives. Currently, she works from 7:00 a.m. until 10:00 p.m. every day. She sells rice, oil, meats, soft drinks, etc. 

With the loan, she would like to buy rice, sugar and soft drinks so that she can expand her store. In the future, she would like to see her store grow so she can have more income and ensure a living for her family.

loans.use: Buying rice, sugar and soft drinks

loans.name: Tania Frineti

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal  “ÑAHUPACMAN PURISUN ”;  El banco comunal está ubicado en el distrito de Huanchac, provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra.  Tania;   ella tiene 34 años de edad, es soltera,  y tiene 1 hijo, La socia alterna sus actividades D. hogar con el comercio minorista, la socia compra y vende ropa de forma independiente ella tiene sus clientes a los cuales frecuentemente les trae novedades como chompas, polos, pantalones; entre otros. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar ropas de temporada y venderlas.

La  socia agradece y valora el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y D. mismo modo se compromete en cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The member belongs to the “ÑAHUPACMAN PURISUN” communal bank. The communal bank is located in the district of Huanchac, province of Cusco and department of Cusco.

The member is Mrs. Tania; she is 34 years old, is single and has a child. The member varies her activities in her home with those of a retailer.
